utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
I wasn't very good.
This was 1953, and I was the slowest typer in eastern Virginia, and my big fingers didn't fit the keys, and the woman I replaced who was on maternity leave had her baby, and they said I could go now.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It was a short assignment.

My main question is with convergence and the kind of fast-paced technology, what - and I kind of - we've been sort of gearing toward that, in terms of radio being the hope for news sort of - not broadcast but news.
What do you believe the news going to look like in maybe 2012?
And then maybe - you know, over a span of time, gradually up until maybe 2050 when we're like, whoa, what is this going to - I think it's going to be scary, but - what's your opinion on that?
Well, Bob took a crack at it, and he didn't do any better than I would, which is we don't know.
We really don't know.
The whole - that whole world is in such tumult, and every year, every month, virtually, brings a new development, that there's just no way of predicting what it will be like.
You mentioned convergence, which was a major fad - I always think of it as a fad - where - when a newspaper owns a radio station and a TV station, the reporters, in effect, commingle.
And they use each other's reports.
A newspaper man will file his piece, but then he'll do a radio version of it, and even do television.
I don't know whether that's working or not.
The first-hand experience I've had with it was in Florida.
And I don't think it was a success.
Because I think there is a built-in - it's not an animosity, but there is a slight confrontational feeling between television reporters and newspaper reporters.
One looking down on the other, and I'll not tell you which looks down.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I sort of saw that at the Times-Dispatch in Richmond, kind of the...
Did you?
Yeah.
You have videos of...
We should point out, Roger Mudd, would have continued in the newspaper business had a radio station not offered him five bucks more a week, and thus a broadcasting career was born.
But what is happening is that all of these entities are competitors, you know, the newspapers, the television, and now the web, the radio.
They're all competing for the same sources of revenue, in order to pay for these very expensive operations that they have.
And there are so many more of them.
And that's why nobody really knows - Roger talked about - have the changes come about?
Is it the people on television?
Or is it the public that is causing the great changes that are going on?
But the driving factor here is the technology.
The technology is just moving so fast that nobody knows what the next chapter of this is going to be.
And how you're going to pay for it.

There used to be a lot of these bureaus, but now, with so many different entities competing for the same advertising dollar, it's much harder for any of them to finance these very expensive operations.
Say hello to them in Richmond, Ms. Blackwell.
I will.
Thank you.
Let's get Tom on the line, Tom with us from Shelter Island in New York.
Hi.
How are you?
Very well, thanks.
I just wanted to say this is a great show and I'm so happy to listen to two reporters who I grew up with in the '60s.

I was 14 when John Kennedy was shot, and I just think that everything that I've listened to of any importance has been uttered by either somebody in the audience - I mean, either Bob or Walter Cronkite.
And I wanted to just say...
You might have tossed Roger Mudd a bone there, you know?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, thank you very much.
You know, I mean, when somebody tells me they have read my book, and I'm sure Roger would probably agree with this.
His book is just out.
That is just the greatest compliment.
You know, people say, I found something - and I wonder about this, Roger.
People will say I saw you on TV.
Oh, you did?
What did you see?
Well, I remember I saw you on TV.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And then people say, I heard what you said on the radio.
And my general feeling is that people pay more attention on the radio.
But when they say they've read your book, that means they've spent a lot of time.
And I - to me - that's the thing that means the most to me.
Thank you very much.
Thanks for the call, Tom.
And our thanks to Roger Mudd and Bob Schieffer for being with us here at the Newseum.
Roger Mudd's new book, ""The Place to Be: Washington, CBS, and the Glory Days of Television News.
It's really good, too.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Coming up - in Cuba, Raul Castro has instituted some changes.
You can make phone calls there now on a cell.
We'll talk about it.
This is NPR News.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
This morning, the New York Philharmonic confirmed plans to perform in Pyongyang, North Korea in late February.
The orchestra then goes on to play in the capital of South Korea, Seoul.
The State Department hails the agreement as a symbol of warming or at least less frigid relations between the United States and the country President Bush once included as part of the axis of evil.
Among the orchestra's conditions for the trip was a promise that they could play ""The Star-Spangled Banner"" and that the concert be broadcast so anybody in North Korea can hear it.
Zarin Mehta, president and executive director of the New York Philharmonic joins us in a moment.
If you want to talk to him about the hows and whys of the visit to North Korea, 800-989-8255.
E-mail: talk@npr.org.
Zarin Mehta is with us by phone from New York, and it's nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today.
Thank you.
I'm delighted to be here.
And whose idea was this?

We're not quite sure but it came out of conversations between the State Department and their foreign ministry as a possible good sign of the relations between the two countries and after that we received an official invitation from the ministry of culture.
And when we received it, we went to the State Department and said what is this all about.
And so, they said, well, I think it'd be a good idea if you could go.
So then you went on to do a preliminary visitâ€¦
Yeah.
We had meetings here to see whether it would work and when we could do it, and then, yeah - and then we went to see them.
And I understand - well, obviously a lot of things had to be arranged, but among them, the orchestra set some conditions for the trip.
Well, in the introduction you said that I set a condition about the national anthem, that wasn't a condition.

That was purely a statement that that's what we would do and it was done on the basis that we will determine the program we pick - that's how we normally do tours - and it would not be any different in Pyongyang.
And I have to say that the North Korean concert people and foreign office people that we met were extremely accommodating in everything we wanted and how we wanted to do things.
I understood that the idea of a broadcast to the entire country though was also a fundamental part of the trip.
Well, it was a very strong suggestion from our staff that it would be a good idea.
And in addition, of course, to playing ""The Star-Spangled Banner,"" do you plan to play the North Korean anthem?
Absolutely.
Yes.
And what does that go like?
I have no idea.
(Soundbite of laughter)
We brought the music back but I haven't heard it yet.
And what else is going to be on the program, do you know?
